        return TheMeaningOfLife
    }
}

func createMaze(height int, width int) Maze {
    //create the maze
}

func main() {
    mazeData := createMaze(1000, 10000)
    maze := Maze{mazeData}
    clones := make([]Clone, 1000000)
    for i := range clones {
        clones[i] = Clone{id: i}
        go clones[i].findExit(maze)
    }
}
Don‚Äôt be intimidated.

Ok, quite a bit to explain.

Let‚Äôs start small ;)

type LocationProps struct {
    next []string
    final string
}
struct ~= JS constructor but with only properties, no methods

Struct? This is similar to creating a constructor in JS and associating two properties. But you must specify the type of your properties and you cannot give a default value.

On to a nested struct:

type Location struct {
    props LocationProps
}
type Maze struct {
    Location
    Directions [][]int
    Height int
    Width int
}
Notice how structs are being passed into structs ~= nesting objects

Now! Nested structs. So I can do this‚Ä¶ maze.Location.props.final.

And what is this? [][] . It means this: [[],[]]. This is the type, two arrays inside of an array, extremely complex.

Onto interfaces:

type CloneAction interface {
    goDifLocation(location string)
    findExit(m Maze)
}
interfaces ~= floating method constructors

Now what? Think of these as‚Ä¶ floating method constructors! In Go they are called interfaces! Once you associate them with a struct, the struct can call them. Prior to that, nothing can call them.

Though, there is another step, the function must associate with the struct:

func (*c Clone) goDifLocation(l string) {
  /*c.goDifLocation can now occur in different functions*/
}
First parentheses is the struct associated

As the comments say. Methods associated with a specific struct is classified in this way.

But now there are functions, and what is with the *? Surely you‚Äôve heard of a pointer but what does this mean in terms of Go? If you write this elsewhere: &c.goDifLocation(...) the variable of type Clone, c in this case, is‚Ä¶ mutated! Sound familiar? If you want to read more about mutations: There is no pass-by-reference in Go.

Back to the function! The parameter: (l string). Yes, it must also be given a specific type. Also, it is common to give short names in Go for parameter names, hence the l for location.

Next, a more detailed function:

func (c Clone) findExit(m Maze) TheMeaningOfLife {/*...*/}
Adding function to struct, specific parameter, specific return value

1, 2, 3, 4 things? Well, yes, that is the reality.

(c clone) - Ex. somethingOfTypeClone.findExit‚Ä¶

findExit‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThis is the name of the function

(m Maze) - Ex. somethingOfTypeClone.findExit(somethingOfTypeMaze)

Lastly, the return value! TheMeaningOfLife

The function as a whole:

func (c Clone) findExit(m Maze) TheMeaningOfLife {
    var currentLocation string
    if len(m.location.props.next) == 3 {
        currentLocation = &c.goDifLocation(
            m.Location.props.next[rand.Intn(
                len(m.location.props.next))])
    }
    //... etc.
    if currentLocation == m.location.props.final {
        return TheMeaningOfLife
    }
}
The meaning of life

Now the function. Check out the first line: var currentLocation string. Again, always remember: type is necessary.

Notice how I initialised currentLocation out of the if statement? Sound familiar? Lexical scope! That link has a nice gist to explain if you do not know.

And the if statement? No parentheses allowed! Wonderful, no? Solely double equals. Again, much nicer than JS. But know this, the curly braces are required. If you throw in an else statement? A short explanation: Go by Example: If/Else. Basically, what should be known is that the else or else if must be on the same line of the ending bracket‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää} else {...

And the convoluted grabbing of a particular index. Let me simply say, a number between 1 and 3 is found. rand is a library, as is math that must be imported at the beginning of the file. A link if you are curious: Packages. Though grabbing random numbers is a bit complicated in Go.

Onto the main function:

func main() {
    mazeData := createMaze(1000, 10000)
    maze := Maze{mazeData}
    clones := make([]Clone, 1000000)
    for i := range clones {
        clones[i] = Clone{id: i}
        go clones[i].findExit(maze)
    }
}
main is the main man in town

Main is what is all that is executed when you the file, as in, all that is in this function will be what is outputted or returned.

What‚Äôs := about? Implicit type. And yes, functions return values in similar way‚Äôs as in JS. Maze{ mazeData } is creating the struct with the mazeData as the values associated to it.

Assume that mazeData looks like this:

{
  Location: {
    next:["a1","a2","a3"],//or the like
    final:"z99"
  }
  Directions: [[/*giant*/][/*array*/]],
  Height: 1000,
  Width: 10000
}

Each value needed for the structs are filled out. Or a zero value is given if they are not.

As for: make([]Clone, 1000000). This is called a slice. An array is created filled with 1000000 types of this struct, but all of them are empty!

for i := range clones {
    clones[i] = Clone{id: i}
    go clones[i].findExit(maze)
}
Concurrency!

The last bit of code. The for := range is similar to a forEach of the clones array. Though, the first argument is always the index, the second can be the actual instance. I am setting the id of each clone and‚Ä¶

Go Routines!!!!!

You type this and every single clone goes into it‚Äôs own process to find it‚Äôs way through the maze. All going different directions BUT heading to the same goal! Concurrency in a nutshell.
